Items.text: Clinical research coordinators like Netsanet, Fergie, and Tania request records for OSP participants, in order to gain a comprehensive view of procedure and treatment history.

Items.title: Project Advisory Council
Items.text: We are so grateful to the PACs that worked with us to build the OSP. Every page of this site was built with their partnership and with this community in mind. Learn more about each one of them on the About Us page.

Items.title: This is not just a box
Items.text: Each saliva and blood sample we receive from OSP participants represents an important contribution towards future research. This powerful way to contribute can enhance our understanding of osteosarcoma and accelerate future discoveries.

step.Button: Download printable PDF to share with your care team

introduction.Text: The Osteosarcoma Project (OSproject) is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research. Count Me In is stewarded by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital; and Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization. Count Me In's Osteosarcoma (OS) Project is supported by a grant from the National Cancer Institute's Cancer Moonshot program and is part of the Participant Engagement and Cancer Genome Sequencing (PE-CGS) Network of research centers. By partnering directly with patients, we can accelerate discoveries in osteosarcoma, leading to the development of new therapies and treatment strategies.

WISection.Title: What is the goal of the Osteosarcoma Project?
WISection.Text: The goal of the OSproject is to transform cancer care by enabling all patients who have ever been diagnosed with osteosarcoma to accelerate biomedical research through sharing their cancer samples, clinical information, and their experiences. In order to achieve these goals, datasets containing linked clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data (without including any personal information) will be regularly shared with the biomedical research community through scientific repositories such as cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics and the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Genomic Data Commons.

WISection.Title: What steps are involved for participants?
WISection.Text: Participants register for the study online at OSproject.org. By consenting to the study, patients allow us to request and obtain copies of their medical records, archived tumor samples (if available), and a saliva and optional blood sample. If desired, the participant may also opt-in to providing an additional saliva sample to learn more about their germline (or “normal”) DNA, described in further detail later on this page.

WISection.Title: What steps are involved for the physician’s offices of enrolled participants?
WISection.Text: When they enroll, participants provide information about where they have received care for their osteosarcoma. The study team works directly with medical record and pathology departments to obtain copies of medical records and portions of archived tumor samples. We will ask pathology departments to share only a part of tumor tissue, and not to share anything with us that might be needed for clinical care.

WISection.Title: Do participants receive individual results back from this study?
WISection.Text:
If a participant elects to share archive tissue samples with the project, we may be able to share information about what we learned from the genomic sequencing of the tumor sample back with the participant. This information is intended to highlight how participant sample(s) are contributing to research and will not have implications for their treatment or prognosis. Because of regulatory restrictions, we are unable to share results with participants in New York and Canada.

The project is also partnering with Invitae in order to sequence and share information on germline DNA (or “normal” DNA) from saliva samples. During the project, participants will be able to decide if they would like to provide an additional saliva sample to learn more about their normal DNA and speak with a genetic counselor to understand these results. If a participant chooses not to participate in this process, their data will not be shared with Invitae. This process is not available for participants in Canada, as Invitae is not licensed to provide genetic counseling services there.

WISection.Title: What makes this project different from existing studies?
WISection.Text: The Osteosarcoma Project seeks to empower patients and families to accelerate cancer research by sharing their samples, clinical information, and experiences with the research community. Most patients are cared for in community settings where genomic studies are not typically conducted, so this study connects osteosarcoma patients around the country with genomics research performed at the Broad Institute, allowing them to participate regardless of where they live. The study was designed in partnership with osteosarcoma patients, families, advocates, and advocacy groups, who continue to provide input on future directions.

WISection.Title: How is the genomic and clinical data shared with the research community?
WISection.Text: Next generation sequencing (whole exome and transcriptome sequencing) is performed on tumor and germline DNA. Sequencing data are linked to de-identified clinical information, and the resulting data are used to identify drivers of tumorigenesis, mechanisms of response and resistance to therapies, and diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic biomarkers. The database of clinically annotated genomic information is shared on publicly available platforms such as cBioPortal and the NIH.

WISection.Title: What kinds of questions is this project aiming to address?
WISection.Text:
Over the past decade, genomic characterization of tumors has shed enormous light on the molecular underpinnings of cancer. These discoveries have led to the development of novel therapies and preventive measures that have already revolutionized cancer care. Despite this progress, the genomics of osteosarcoma remains poorly understood.

The types of questions we strive to answer include:

• What are all the genes and mutations that can lead to osteosarcoma?
• What explains why some patients show extraordinary responses to a particular treatment?
• What explains why some tumors never respond to a particular treatment?
• How can we develop better treatments for osteosarcoma?

Despite the progress that has been made to begin to answer these questions, we remain far from the goal. To get there, the detailed genomic characterization of many thousands of clinically annotated cancer samples will be required.

If you have any questions about this study, please reach out to us at info@OSproject.org or 651-602-2020.

The Osteosarcoma Project is part of Count Me In

IntroSection.Title: For your physician
IntroSection.Text: The purpose of this page is to provide details about the Osteosarcoma Project to your physician and care team so they can learn more about the project. You can show them this website, or print out a PDF below with the same information to discuss at your next appointment

DashboardIntro.isParent:
Thank you for being part of the Osteosarcoma project. This page contains links to your forms and surveys that are part of the study. Over time, we may add additional surveys for your consideration. The information you provide will help drive our understanding of cancer.

If at any time you have questions or would like to share updated information, please contact the study team at info@osproject.org or call 651-602-2020.
DashboardIntro.isChild:
Thank you for being part of the Osteosarcoma project. This page contains links to your child’s forms and surveys that are part of the study. Over time, we may add additional surveys for your consideration. The information you provide will help drive our understanding of cancer.

If at any time you have questions or would like to share updated information, please contact the study team at info@osproject.org or call 651-602-2020.
DashboardIntro.isLovedOne:
Thank you for being part of the Osteosarcoma Project and sharing your Loved One’s experience with osteosarcoma. This page contains a link that will take you to the survey so you can complete it.

If at any time you have questions or would like to share updated information, please contact the study team at info@osproject.org or call 651-602-2020.

IntroductionSection.Title: Together, the osteosarcoma community has the power to move research forward
IntroductionSection.Text: By generating the most comprehensive osteosarcoma database, we can accelerate research and the development of new therapies. Only you hold the key to unlock future discoveries.

ClosingSection.Title: Please join us in saying “Count Me In!”
ClosingSection.Text: With your help, the osteosarcoma community can be the driving force behind transformative research.

MailingListSection.Title: Want to stay informed on the OS Project?
MailingListSection.Text: We'll keep you up-to-date on developments, you can unsubscribe at any time.

Step1.Text: Share your experiences, access to medical records, and samples.

Step2.Text: The anonymous study data is shared widely with the biomedical community so all may learn together.

Step3.Text: This will accelerate the ability of researchers to make discoveries.

Step4.Text: In some cases, we may be able to share learnings from the genomic sequencing of your samples back with you.

Diagnosed.Title: If you or your child have ever been diagnosed with osteosarcoma
Diagnosed.Text: You can make an impact by telling us about your or your child’s cancer. Share experiences, access to medical records, a saliva sample, and if you choose, tissue and blood samples to drive new discoveries. Depending on the age at enrollment, patients may enroll themselves. Younger patients will need the help of their parents.

PassedAway.Title: If your child has passed away from osteosarcoma
PassedAway.Text: You can make an impact by answering questions about your child’s diagnosis and experiences to advance our understanding of osteosarcoma.

AllowList.Title: You can choose to allow the study team to:
AllowList.Option1: send you a simple kit to collect a saliva sample
AllowList.Option2: request copies of your medical records

Opt-inToList.Title: You may also opt-in to:
Opt-inToList.Option2: allowing the team to request a portion of tumor tissue (if available)
Opt-inToList.Option3: receiving information about what we've learned from the genomic sequencing of your / your child's tumor sample (if we are able to send these to you)
Opt-inToList.Option4: providing an additional saliva sample to learn more about your/your child's normal DNA with the help of a genetic counselor

ClosingText.Part2: — with your permission, we’ll obtain copies of your medical records and send you a saliva kit.

StayInformedSection.Title: Stay informed

CountMeInSection.Title: Join the movement and say Count Me In
CountMeInSection.Text: With your help, patients can be the driving force behind transformative cancer research.

Steps.Title: Provide consent for the study
Steps.Text: The consent form is how participants give researchers their permission to take part in the study. This section consists of several pages, we encourage participants to take their time. Any progress will be automatically saved and can be re-accessed later. For participants who are signing up for / with their child, depending on their age, we may also ask the child to “assent” or agree that they would also like to participate in the study.
Steps.ImageAlt: Computer screen displaying online consent form

Steps.Title: Tell us where you’ve been treated
Steps.Text: We ask where patients have been treated for their cancer, so that we can request medical records, and if applicable, archived tumor tissue.

Steps.Title: Respond to surveys about you and your experience with cancer
Steps.Text: In these surveys we ask questions about a participant’s experience with osteosarcoma, like when they were diagnosed and the types of treatments they've had.

Steps.Title: Provide a saliva and/or blood sample
Steps.Text: We will send participants a kit to collect a sample of their saliva and/or blood, along with easy to follow instructions. We will study these samples to help improve our understanding of cancer by comparing the normal DNA in a participant's saliva or blood to their tumor DNA from any tumor samples we may collect.

Participations.Text: Over time, we will provide participants with regular updates about the status of the research and share any discoveries that they have enabled us to make. We may also contact participants to participate in focus groups or provide additional feedback related to the overall project experience — we want to hear what’s important to you.
Participations.ImageAlt: Speech bubbles sharing hearts and data visualizations

Participations.step: Receive information about what we've learned from your tumor sample, if you choose
Participations.Text: If participants choose to share archive tissue samples with the project, we may be able to share information about what we've learned from the genomic sequencing of a participant's tumor sample back with them. This information is intended to highlight how participants are contributing to research and will not have implications for their treatment or prognosis. Because of regulatory restrictions, we are unable to share results with participants in New York and Canada.
Participations.Button: What types of information is shared about tumor samples?
Participations.Button1: Download printable PDF to share with your care team

Participations.step: Learn more about your normal DNA, if you choose
Participations.Text: The OSproject is also partnering with Invitae in order to sequence and share information on germline DNA (or “normal” DNA) from saliva samples. During the project, participants will be able to decide if they’d like to provide an additional saliva sample to learn more about their/their child’s normal DNA and speak with a genetic counselor to understand these results. If a participant chooses not to participate in this process, their data will not be shared with Invitae. This process is not available for participants in Canada, as Invitae is not licensed to provide genetic counseling services there.

PASection.Text: The goal of the OSproject is to transform cancer care by enabling all patients who have ever been diagnosed with osteosarcoma to accelerate biomedical research through sharing their cancer samples, clinical information, and their experiences. In order to achieve these goals, datasets containing linked clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data (without including any personal information) will be regularly shared with the biomedical research community through scientific repositories such as cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics and the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Genomic Data Commons.

Desc: • Surveys: All participants in the OSproject will be able to provide patient-reported data through a series of surveys during enrollment and over time.
• Saliva and Blood samples: Participants will also be able to provide Saliva and Blood samples, which provide us with information about their DNA.

• Medical Records: The project team requests copies of medical records from all institutions where participants have received care. This allows the project to understand a participant's history of treatments, procedures, and other clinical details.

• Tumor Samples: Participants may give us permission to request stored tumor samples from institutions where they have been treated. These are used together with saliva and blood samples to generate genomic and molecular data for analysis.

• Interviews or focus groups: Some participants will also be contacted to participate in focus groups or provide additional feedback related to the overall project experience and their perspectives on participating in genomic research.
Examples of important documents such as the consent form, surveys, and kit instructions can be found on our Participation page.

ELSection.Text: Thanks to the participation and contributions of patients enrolled in the OSproject, we will be able to release several types of data to the research community, allowing researchers to analyze many different aspects of how osteosarcoma works. The types of data we collect includes:
Desc: • Genomic Information: Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) information will be included for tumor samples, including mutations, small insertions/deletions, amplifications, and deletions.

• Medical Record Information: Information about diagnosis and treatment will be abstracted from patients’ medical records. These responses will be modified and formatted to prevent individual identification without altering scientific utility.
• Pathology Report Information: Detailed histologic information about each sample will be abstracted from pathology reports associated with each sample.

•Patient-reported Data (PRD): Every patient that registers for the study has the option of completing multiple surveys about their experiences with osteosarcoma. Select questions from these surveys will be abstracted for inclusion. These responses will be modified and formatted to prevent individual identification without altering scientific utility.
  • Specific types of questions include those about:
    • Demographic and diagnostic information
    • Information about any treatments and surgeries received
    • The current location(s) / status of the participant’s osteosarcoma
    • A place for participants to share any additional information that they’d like about their osteosarcoma
    • A participant’s family history of cancer
    • A participant’s current treatments for osteosarcoma
    • A participant’s current quality of life

WDSection.Paragraph4: What does a data release look like?
WDSection.Text: Below are links out to publicly available datasets from other Count Me In projects. This is what we’re working towards for the Osteosarcoma Project. If you have questions about our data release process, please email us at info@OSproject.org.

TermSection.Text: • For reference to common terms used in cancer care and research, the National Cancer Institute has developed a Dictionary of Cancer Terms, found here.

Text.Main: The Osteosarcoma Project is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.

CMISection.Paragraph1: is stewarded by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and Emerson Collective.
CMISection.Paragraph2: Count Me In's Osteosarcoma (OS) Project is supported by a grant from the National Cancer Institute's Cancer Moonshot program and is part of the Participant Engagement and Cancer Genome Sequencing (PE-CGS) Network of research centers.
CMISection.Paragraph3: The Osteosarcoma Project has been designed and implemented collaboratively with osteosarcoma patients, advocates, caregivers, loved ones, cancer researchers, and clinicians.

PACSection.Title: Project Advisory Council
PACSection.Text: The Osteosarcoma Project Advisory Council (PAC) is made up of patients, advocates, caregivers, and loved ones who have been impacted by osteosarcoma. The PAC meets regularly with the project operations team via video calls to develop all aspects of the project, including survey questions, the project website, the project name and logo, and sample kits.

Members.Name: Theresa Beech
Members.Bio: Theresa Beech is the mother of two kids, Daniel and Sara. When Daniel was 11, he was diagnosed with osteosarcoma. Two years later, at the age of 13, he was dead. Daniel had a smile that would light up a room, and all throughout treatment, he never quit smiling. While Daniel was on hospice, Theresa taught herself genomics and started doing research into osteosarcoma genetics. She was able to identify two drugs which corresponded to mutations in Daniel’s tumor and prolonged his life. Since Daniel’s death on August 28, 2016, she has continued her patient advocacy and genomics research and is the Principal Investigator of POWR, the Patient/parent Osteosarcoma genome-Wide Registry, believed to be one of the largest genomic and medical history registry of osteosarcoma data in the world. She has presented her research findings at numerous scientific conferences in the US and internationally, and has been invited to speak at a variety of forums. A TV long-story on Daniel and her work won the prestigious National 2018 June L. Biedler Award for TV journalism. In 2019, she started a closed Facebook group called the Osteosarcoma Information Group to provide scientific and medical information and explanations to osteosarcoma patients and their families. Today, there are well over 500 members and doctors and researchers are now joining the group as well. She is the founder and President of “Because of Daniel '', a charitable foundation dedicated to osteosarcoma research and clinical trials. She is also a co-founder and board member of the Osteosarcoma Collaborative, a charitable foundation dedicated to promoting collaboration in osteosarcoma. In her day job, Theresa is a space engineer (aka rocket scientist) for NASA.

Members.Name: Ann Graham
Members.Bio: Ann is the founder and President of MIB Agents Osteosarcoma Alliance. At age 43, Ann was diagnosed with osteosarcoma and was treated in the Pediatric Center at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. She was in awe of the courage of her fellow patients. Like most, she was unaware of how little funding pediatric cancers receive, and that osteosarcoma patients lose limbs, fertility, hearing, organ function and too often, their lives. She knew there had to be a way to Make It Better. She began MIB Agents, a nationwide 501c3 non-profit and the FACTOR Conference. Together with MIB Agents everywhere, they endeavor to Make It Better for osteosarcoma patients. She is an Advocate with the A2A Alliance, The Mighty, and a member of CAC2.

Members.Name: Alexis Johnson
Members.Bio: Alexis Johnson is a 12-year Osteosarcoma Cancer survivor and an amputee. During her treatment, Alexis spent countless hours in the hospital and became close with the patients around her. It was here that she met some of the most incredible children who never let their illness stand in their way. She watched them bravely battle Osteosarcoma and many losing their fight due to exhausting all treatment options. Alexis learned that there has been no new treatments and not enough research done. This drove Alexis to wanting to do something to help change this outcome. Alexis has dedicated her life to becoming an advocate in the fight against Osteosarcoma. She is involved in the wonderful organization MIB and worked on several initiatives with them. She has also used the power of her voice to raise awareness and help others who are currently in the fight. Alexis is currently in medical school at the University of Arizona with an end goal of becoming a pediatric oncologist. She is tremendously proud to be a part of this project and understands what the power of knowledge and data can do to greatly change this outcome.

Members.Name: Ryan Kennington
Members.Bio: At the age of 17 years old, Ryan was diagnosed with Osteosarcoma in the femoral head of his right femur. At the University of Pennsylvania Abramson Cancer Center, he underwent treatment and a limb salvaging surgery. One year after he completed treatment, he had a relapse in his lungs and had a video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery to remove the single nodule. Today, Ryan has been cancer free for over 4 years and is enjoying life free of disease. Active in the cancer community, Ryan is involved in non-profit organizations such as MIB agents, Steps to Cure Sarcoma, and UDANCE in order to help raise awareness and funds for cancer research. Motivated by his experiences with Osteosarcoma, he is currently working on earning his Bachelor of Science degree in biology at the University of Delaware and is focusing his attention on improving the outcome of Osteosarcoma patients.

Members.Name: Ben Moody
Members.Bio: Ben Moody is the father of Claire, who was diagnosed with osteosarcoma in 2012 and who passed away in 2016, aged 24.  She was a bright light; she lit up every room. Claire was irrepressibly happy; teeming with energy, she flapped, she twirled, she loved to laugh. One of Claire’s many doctors wrote “Claire is an inspiration to all of us that care for sarcoma patients or do sarcoma research; she is the motivation that pushes us on our journey to find a cure.” Since Claire’s death, Ben has been dedicated to collaborating with those who are passionately focused on finding a cure for osteosarcoma, including as a member of the Board of the Osteosarcoma Collaborative.  Ben is also co-founder of Pan American Finance, an advisory firm based in Miami, Florida, with a key focus on raising capital for renewable energy. Ben has over 35 years of investment banking and private equity experience, and is a graduate of the University of Oxford.

Members.Name: Laura Sobeich
Members.Bio: Laura Sobiech’s son, Zach, died from osteosarcoma at the age of 18. In the last year of Zach’s life, he wrote a song called “Clouds” that became an international hit. After Zach died, Laura wrote a book called Fly a Little Higher: How God Answered a Mom’s Small Prayer in a Big Way, to tell the story of Zach’s battle with osteosarcoma and how he chose to live despite the disease. This year, Laura’s book is being made into a film by Warner Brothers. Laura works at Children’s Cancer Research Fund, a nonprofit that raises seed grant money for research, and where the Zach Sobiech Osteosarcoma Fund was established in 2012. All proceeds from Zach’s music are donated to the fund to support Zach’s wish that no other kids will have to die from osteosarcoma.

Members.Name: Brian Crompton
Affiliations: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

Members.Name: Alejandro Sweet-Cordero
Affiliations: Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center

Members.Name: Richard Gorlick
Affiliations: The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

Members.Name: Brian Crompton
Affiliations: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

LearnMoreSection.Text: Learn more about the Osteosarcoma Project

IntroText.Paragraph1: As part of the OSproject, patients contribute their experiences, clinical information, and samples to make data freely available for any OS researchers. By generating the most comprehensive dataset for OS, the entire cancer research community can make discoveries that can lead to a better understanding of the disease and changes for future treatments. The project is part of Count Me In, a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research. The project also works in collaboration with a growing coalition of nonprofit advocacy partners.

Paragraph2.Part1: This project has been built with the guidance and input of many different members of the OS community. Below we have answered some general questions about this project, as well as questions that are specific to different members of the community - please read any and all that may apply. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to us at

Items.Question: What is the goal of the OSproject?
Paragraphs: The goal of the OSproject is to transform cancer care by enabling all patients who have ever been diagnosed with osteosarcoma to accelerate biomedical research through sharing their cancer samples, clinical information, and their experiences. In order to achieve these goals, datasets containing linked clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data (without including any personal information) will be regularly shared with the biomedical research community through scientific repositories such as cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics and the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Genomic Data Commons.

Items.Question: What does participation look like?
Paragraphs: Participants can join through the project website to share their information and experiences with us.

• Provide consent: The consent form is how participants give researchers their permission to take part in the study. It will also allow people to elect to share samples of saliva, blood, and/or tissue, as well as copies of their medical records. This document is several pages, but we encourage participants to take their time and reach out to the project team with any questions.
• Tell us where you’ve been treated: We ask where participants have been treated, so that we can request medical records, and if applicable, archived tumor tissue.

• Respond to surveys: In these surveys we ask questions about a participant’s experience with OS, like when they were diagnosed and the types of treatments they've had. Participants may also be contacted by the team to participate in focus groups or additional surveys about their experiences participating in the project.

• Provide a saliva and/or blood sample: We will send participants a kit to collect a sample of their saliva and/or blood, along with easy to follow instructions. We will study these samples to help improve our understanding of cancer by comparing the normal DNA in a participant's saliva or blood to their tumor DNA from any tumor samples we may collect.

Items.Question: Are there any benefits that participants receive for participating?
Paragraphs: While there are no explicit benefits that individuals receive for enrolling in the OSproject, the project offers some optional opportunities to become more involved that may be of interest to participants looking to learn more about the samples they provide.

• Receive information about what we’ve learned from your tumor sample (optional): If a participant elects to share archive tissue samples with the project, we may be able to share information from the genomic sequencing of the tumor sample back with the participant. This information is intended to highlight how participant sample(s) are contributing to research and will not have implications for their treatment or prognosis. Because of regulatory restrictions, we are unable to share results with participants in New York and Canada.

• Learn more about your normal DNA (optional): The project is also partnering with Invitae in order to sequence and share information on germline DNA (or “normal” DNA) from saliva samples. During the project, participants will be able to decide if they would like to provide an additional saliva sample to learn more about their normal DNA and speak with a genetic counselor to understand these results. If a participant chooses not to participate in this process, their data will not be shared with Invitae. This process is not available for participants in Canada, as Invitae is not licensed to provide genetic counseling services there.

Items.Question: Who is conducting this research?
Paragraphs: This project is being conducted by the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, and Count Me In, a non-profit research initiative that conducts patient-partnered studies of cancer. Count Me In's Osteosarcoma (OS) Project and Leiomyosarcoma (LMS) Project are supported by a grant from the National Cancer Institute's Cancer Moonshot program and are part of the Participant Engagement and Cancer Genome Sequencing (PE-CGS) Network of research centers.

Items.Question: Who is eligible to participate?
Paragraphs: Anyone who has been diagnosed with osteosarcoma (OS) at any point may participate if they live in the USA or Canada. We welcome people of all ages, genders, races, ethnicities, and abilities.

If you are a parent of a child diagnosed with OS, you can provide consent for them to participate in the project. Depending on their age, we may also ask them to provide permission to participate through assent.

At this time, we are only able to obtain samples and medical records from patients who live in the United States and Canada, as there are regulatory restrictions that do not allow us to obtain saliva, blood, tumor samples and medical records from international patients.

Items.Question: Are there any costs for participants to participate?
Paragraphs: No, there are no costs for the participant associated with any step in the project.

Items.Question: Is this research being conducted for profit?
Paragraphs: No. This project is a not-for-profit research endeavor. Our mission is to generate, aggregate, and freely share data with the research community in order to accelerate discoveries. All data shared with the research community will have readily identifiable information removed.

Items.Question: How has the OS community been involved in the design of this project?
Paragraphs: We have worked closely with patients, parents, and patient advocates within the OS community from the beginning of this project through its design and implementation. The community has been involved in all aspects including concept, goals, messaging, surveys, and the design of this website. The project also partners with leading researchers working in OS.
We're proud to have our Advocacy Partners MIB Agents, QuadW, The Zach Sobiech Osteosarcoma Fund, Because of Daniel, and The Osteosarcoma Collaborative to partner with and support this project.

Items.Question: Is this study a clinical trial?
Paragraphs: This study is not a clinical trial. A clinical trial is “a type of research study that tests how well new medical approaches work in people. These studies test new methods of screening, prevention, diagnosis, or treatment of a disease.“

Participation in the OSproject will not have any impact on the participant’s course of care for osteosarcoma. We are not permitted to give any clinical advice as part of participation in this project. The testing we are performing is for research and may not provide information about a participant’s tumor that would lead to changes in their care and treatment plan.

If participants elect to share tumor samples with the project and we are able to successfully sequence sample(s), we  will share what we’ve learned from tumor sequencing with participants. When a participant consents to the study, they will be able to choose whether or not to receive this information. An example of what this information could look like can be found

In some cases, we may not be able to share what we’ve learned from tumor sequencing with participants. Because of regulatory restrictions, we are unable to share results with participants living in or samples from institutions in New York and Canada. More details on NY state restrictions can be found here.

Items.Question: What is the difference between tumor and germline DNA?
Paragraphs: Tumors are made of cells in a person's body whose DNA has mutated so they are no longer healthy and normally-functioning. A person’s  germline (also called “normal”) DNA is the DNA that is in all the healthy cells in the body. We can compare a person’s tumor DNA to the germline to learn more about the genetic mutations that are present in their cancer. Germline testing looks at the “normal” DNA in a person’s body. This is sometimes done to see if there is a mutation present that may have been inherited.

Items.Question: How is this different from clinical/commercial genomic testing?
Paragraphs: There are many types of genetic testing, also called sequencing. Clinical-grade genetic sequencing is done in a particular type of lab (called a CLIA lab) that has stricter parameters to make sure that the data produced meets certain quality standards. Our genetic sequencing is clinical-grade and done in a CLIA lab, so we are able to share what we’ve learned from participants' tumor samples with them.

There are also different types of genetic sequencing depending on what a researcher or physician is interested in. A panel test might be ordered to look at one or several segments of DNA (called genes) that are already known to have an impact on humans if mutated.

This project performs Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) on tumor samples, meaning that we look at all of the parts of the DNA that are being used by the body to make proteins. For germline sequencing, Invitae will conduct a panel test for specific genes known to be associated with sarcoma, many of these genes are also associated with an increased risk of other cancer types.

Items.Question: Can these results be shared with a participant’s doctor/clinical team?
Paragraphs: The tumor sequencing is performed in a clinical laboratory and so if a participant chooses to share the results with their doctor, their doctor can place the information in the participant's medical record.
If you or your doctor thinks having your tumor sequenced or profiled will help with your care, then we recommend that standard testing for clinical purposes be ordered by your doctor.

Items.Question: Who will use participant samples and see participant information?
Paragraphs: Samples and health information for participants will be available to study staff and researchers at Count Me In, the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. More details about how we protect participant information and samples can be found in the consent form.

After removing a participant’s name and other readily identifiable information, we will share results obtained from their participation with the greater research community via established public scientific databases (for example, the National Institute of Health/National Cancer Institute data portals such as the Genomic Data Commons and dbGaP, and the cBioPortal for Cancer Genomics). Some of these databases are publicly viewable by anyone with internet access, and some are restricted to qualified researchers.

If a participant chooses to have germline sequencing done with Invitae, the project will provide Invitae with the participant’s name and contact information. The data and report generated by Invitae will be shared with the participant and with study staff associated with the project. The germline results from Invitae will not be shared in scientific databases.

FaqSections.Title: I have / my child has been diagnosed with OS

Items.Question: What happens when my child with OS becomes an adult?
Paragraphs: When your child reaches the age where they can consent for themselves, they need to do so to continue to participate in the project. For the US and Canada, this varies by locations and is between ages 18 and 21.

If your child remains in the study when they reach the age where they can consent for themselves, the project team will contact them to re-consent to the study. We will contact you to get your child’s contact information. If your child consents, the project team will continue to request medical records and tissue samples from any point in your child’s treatment.

Items.Question: What if I or my child signed up for the OS project before 2022?
Paragraphs:
If you signed up for the OS project before 2022, there are new, optional opportunities to become more involved if you would like, including:
• Responding to additional surveys
• Receiving information about what we learned from your/your child’s tumor sequencing,
• Learning more about your/your child’s normal DNA.
For more details on the new opportunities, see the FAQ

Paragraphs.content: “Are there any benefits that participants receive for participating?“

Paragraphs: To take part in these activities, please log into your dashboard to sign additional consent forms and provide updates to your/your child’s participation. If you have any questions, please reach out to the study team at info@osproject.org or 651-602-2020.

FaqSections.Title: My child passed away from osteosarcoma

Items.Question: Can I participate if my child has passed away from osteosarcoma?
Paragraphs: Yes. You can click "Count Me In", and there will be an option to indicate that your child has passed away. This will lead to a survey that will ask questions about your child’s experience with osteosarcoma. Your responses will give researchers unique insights into this cancer and has the power to inform future directions for studies in this rare cancer.

We will provide regular updates as the study progresses about the status of the project and information about new studies that we are conducting. We will also share any discoveries from these research projects with you.

Items.Question: Can I provide access to medical records and tissue on behalf of someone who passed away?
Paragraphs: The OSProject cannot currently obtain medical records or tissue samples for individuals who have passed away. We are exploring future plans for a next-of-kin process, but this will take time to develop. Through the Loved Ones survey, you may choose to opt-in to be re-contacted by the study if a process is developed to enable this.

FaqSections.Title: I am a member of the community who would like to get involved

Items.Question: How can I spread the word about the OSProject?
Paragraphs: If you would like to learn more about how to spread the word about the project, or if you have any suggestions or questions about the project, please email us at info@osproject.org.

Items.Question: How can I receive updates on the OSProject?
Paragraphs: If you would like updates on the project, please sign up for our mailing list.

ThankYouFamilyHistory.Title:
Thank you for working with us to make
 this research possible.
ThankYouFamilyHistory.Subtitle:
If you’d like to update or review your answers to this survey, you can access it
 from your dashboard at any time.

StayInformed.Title: Stay informed
StayInformed.Text: Thank you for joining the email list. We'll send you updates and keep you informed. You can unsubscribe at any time. If you have any questions about your status in the project, please email

LovedOneThankYou.Title: Thank you!
LovedOneThankYou.ThankYou: Thank you for taking the time to take the survey and share your Loved One’s experience with osteosarcoma.
LovedOneThankYou.StayInTouch: We’ll stay in touch with you so that you can see the progress that we are making towards advancements in the understanding of osteosarcoma.

Contacts.TextPt1: We'd also like to hear from you if you have any additional thoughts you'd like to share — please feel free to email us at

LovedOneThankYou.ThankYouAgain: Thank you again for sharing with us and supporting the entire osteosarcoma community. If you’d like to help us reach patients or other community members, feel free to share the project. Together, we can move research forward for the osteosarcoma community.
